audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker explaining how to navigate "helioviewer.org". He emphasizes the ability to see what's being learned in chapters about the sun. He suggests a tutorial, and shares he will highlight some useful comparisons. The male speaker's tone is instructional.

The audio clip features a single speaker, a woman, describing an event. She speaks in a conversational tone about attending a day when the sun was active in 2013 and when the Solar Dynamics Observatory was available.

The audio begins with a female speaker describing how Helioviewer can provide imagery and data from various spacecraft. She then mentions that they will focus on a few wavelengths from the Solar Dynamics Observatory, or SDO, and that SDO has several instruments available for investigation. The speaker is speaking in a clear and informative tone.

The clip begins with a female speaker describing "AIA, the atmospheric imaging assembly," identifying it as the one that takes pictures of the sun. She then mentions "HMI" and explains that it deals with magnetic data, stating they won't focus on it. Her tone is informative and professional.

The clip starts with a single female speaker explaining that the measurement here is in Angstroms, discussing wavelengths and the nature of light. Her tone is informational and clear. She then moves on to discuss specific Angstrom values within the visible light range and then explains how shorter wavelengths correlate to extreme ultraviolet light. She clarifies the use of 193 Angstroms, and finishes with describing the Earth to scale so that the viewer can understand the structures they are looking at.

The clip starts with a female speaker, in an informative tone, describing visible and ultraviolet images, highlighting that "this is beneath the layer that we're looking at here." She continues, contrasting the "yellow-colored sun" and the "photosphere", with the "extreme ultraviolet image" and the "corona of the sun." She explains the relative position of the corona above the photosphere.

The audio features a single speaker, presumably female, who seems to be describing something while pointing out key things. She mentions seeing "a really good sunspot group" and notes a lack of sunspots in more recent data, suggesting the sun has been in a minimum. She further mentions "a couple of sunspot groups."

The clip begins with a female speaker describing that underneath sunspot groups there are bright loops of material, what "we call active regions". She then goes on to say that there are three different categories, and that a particular catalog is telling us that that this is one big active region and it has a name. Continuing, the speaker says that these active regions are showing up right where sunspots are and that those two structures are connected. She then explains that sunspots tell us in the visible light that there is strong magnetic field in that area and active regions are showing loops of material that are following along strong magnetic field lines.

The audio clip features a single female speaker who's explaining that the other thing to highlight are "coronal holes." They can toggle features on and off to show that coronal holes are darker places within the corona, where there's less material. She contrasts this with how these regions appear in the photosphere, noting that there's no indication of coronal holes there. She emphasizes this to avoid confusing sunspots with coronal holes, as they look dark in images but are not the same structure.

The audio clip features a single female speaker who discusses coronal holes and sunspots, noting their differences and similarities in appearance and material composition. Her tone is informative and educational. There's a clear emphasis on distinguishing what aspects of these phenomena are related versus unrelated to each other.

The clip begins with a single female speaker summarizing the functionality of a program called "Helio Viewer" and recommends that listeners try it out. She notes the ability to take and download screenshots of selected areas. She ends by thanking the listener and announcing her intention to see them in the next video, speaking in an informative and conversational tone.
